title: Phil Neville claims Ole Gunnar Solskjaer made one mistake in Man Utd's draw with Liverpool
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer brought Anthony Martial on in the 84th minute against Liverpool (Picture: Getty)

Phil Neville believes Manchester United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer got his tactics ‘spot on’ against Liverpool – but feels Anthony Martial should have been introduced sooner at Old Trafford.

United looked on course to pick up just their third win of the Premier League season after Marcus Rashford broke the deadlock in the 36th minute on Sunday afternoon.

However, Liverpool – who had a first-half strike from Sadio Mane ruled out by VAR for handball – managed to maintain their unbeaten record as substitute Adam Lallana found a late equaliser from close range.

Ryan Giggs claimed that Marcos Rojo at fault for Liverpool’s 85th-minute leveller and Neville agreed that the Argentine defender was the man to blame.

Neville felt Martial should have come on sooner at Old Trafford (Picture: Optus Sport)

Neville applauded Solskjaer’s overall game-plan against the league leaders, but argued that the Norwegian missed an opportunity by leaving Martial on the bench until the 84th minute.

Advertisement

‘The momentum did change. I thought the substitutions of [Alex] Oxlade-Chamberlain, Lallana and [Naby] Keita just gave them a bit of impetus in terms of energy and United didn’t make the substitutions,’ Neville told Optus Sport.

‘They brought Martial on… I thought maybe just five or ten minutes too late to change the momentum. You could see that United were camped in.

‘I agree with Ryan… I don’t know what Rojo was doing for the goal. He had no need to go ahead of the other centre-back, he stays in his slot and he picks up Lallana.

‘But I thought it was an outstanding performance from United. Full of energy, they played a more direct style and at the end the fans were dead because of the effort the players put in.

‘They didn’t get their just rewards.’

Neville added: ‘Tactically, Ole got it really spot on today.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘Five at the back, they defended the middle of the pitch really well, the three centre-backs in particular defended the goal really well, every cross that came in from wide areas they were set.

‘Just that cross at the end when it gets fired across the box. Rojo just lost a little bit of concentration and it got punished.

‘Liverpool did finish really strong and United will feel like that’s two points dropped.’

Liverpool players were adamant that Divock Origi was fouled by Victor Lindelof in the build-up to Rashford’s goal, but Solskjaer wasn’t having any of it.

No chance… we’re not playing basketball,’ Solskjaer said.

‘He touched him but it’s not a clear and obvious error. I don’t think it’s a foul.’

Solskjaer was delighted with United’s performance against league leaders Liverpool (Picture: Getty)

Solskjaer hopes his players use their promising display as a springboard for the season after a poor start to the 2019/20 campaign.

‘We are better when he attack quickly, no dilly-dallying on the ball,’ he said.

‘Playing the ball forward doesn’t have to be a counter attack but you need to be more direct, take more risks, be braver.

‘It doesn’t matter if you lose the ball up there because you can win it back. Being more direct helped us.’
